pull.title: Initial gcov work
pull.body: Separation of deterministic tests from randomized tests; initial work for gcov build & run. Next step is filling out deterministic tests to trigger branches.  All feedback welcome.

events.message: introduce state object for random number generator, to make randomized fuzz tests explicit and prevent accidental randomization of deterministic tests
don't use pkgconfig on osx so that openssl can be located
segregate deterministic tests from randomized ones; random number generator state for bignum & openssl tests
parameterize count to further differentiate fuzz testing
only deterministic tests for gcov run
for now, compile in only deterministic tests for gcov build

events.body: Just a quick question I had: Whats the motivation of not running the randomized tests in coverage testing? They're just as deterministic as the rest when run with a static seed.

I think that could get challenging to maintain in practice. In order to guarantee identical test behavior across changes, it'd be necessary to not only never change the RNG algorithm, but also not change the sequence of calls to the RNG (as could happen with adding, removing, or changing the order of tests, for example). Or, statically seed before every test and make sure the intra-test RNG call pattern doesn't change.

Also, for me personally, I find a fixed sequence of instructions used to evoke a specific condition in the code under test is easier to reason confidently about.

There's philosophical motivations as well, upon which I'm happy to expound if you like. :-)
P.S. I'm happy to take a different approach if you prefer.

Hi,

sorry for not commenting on this earlier, but there are several changes in the pipeline which will likely conflict with this, in particular #217, #215, and #208. I'd like to see those go in first.

I'm definitely interested in better automatic coverage tests afterwards, though.
No worries, let me know when you're ready.
Closing as obsolete, we have coverage support for a long time now (https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/426). There's still https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/954 open though.
